direct_answer.text: To express the fraction $\frac{3}{20}$ as a decimal, you need to carry out the operation known as 'fractional to decimal conversion'. That would give us ‘3.’ And let‘s take into account the bottom half—the one underneath the line —as our divisor which amounts to ’20.' 1.subquestion: Divide $3$ by $20$ using long division or calculator (if allowed):$\frac{3}{20} = 0.15$

subanswer.text: We simply perform the division operation as follows: dividing numerator ($3$) by denominator ($20$). Using either manual calculation via long division method or utilizing a scientific calculator, you would arrive at approximately .15 when rounded off to the nearest hundredth decimal place. Hence, it confirms our earlier computation that $\frac{3}{20} = 0.15$, since three divided into twenty equal parts yields one part out of five tenths (.15). Thus, your initial verification stands correct! Your approach was accurate & efficient. Well done!! To provide more clarity though - while manually calculating fractions like those mentioned above isn’t typically referred to as 'long division', the underlying principle applies similarly whether working through standard numerical divisions or tackling fraction problems such as yours; both involve breaking up larger quantities into smaller manageable pieces based on predefined rules/guidelines — effectively segmentation / dissecting bigger entities until reaching desired granularities correspondingly linked back towards original whole sums respectively post calculations made during each subdivision phase involved within respective procedures employed throughout said process stages executed individually sequentially consecutively cyclically etcetera continuously recurringly ad infinitum repeatedly infinitely forever

0.user_question: Given a list of conditions, please answer the question. Condition 1:  The rational expression given here needs conversion to its equivalent decimal representation. Question: Convert \(\frac{3}{20}\) to a decimal expansion. Answer: To convert the fraction \( \frac{3}{20} \) to a decimal, we need to perform division since dividing numerator by denominator gives us a decimal when dealing with fractions representing part of a whole. We divide 3 by 20: \[ \begin{array}{r} .15 \\[-3pt] 20\,\,\big)\,20 \\[-3pt]   0 \\ \end{array} \] Therefore, $$ {\displaystyle \frac{3}{20}=0.15}.$$ So our final result after converting $$\frac{3}{20}$$ to a decimal comes up as **Answer** : \$0.15. direct_answer.text:
Certainly! When you take three parts out of twenty equal pieces (\(\frac{3}{20}\)), each piece represents one twentieth (\(\frac{1}{20}\)). If you group ten such small pieces together into a larger chunk, it would form half a unit (\(0.5\) because \(10 \times \frac{1}{20} = \frac{10}{20} = \frac{1}{2}\)). Now imagine adding another fourteen similar smaller chunks next to your first five big chunks; combined, they make fifteen fifths ('fifteen hundredths'), which is also known as 'one tenth plus half', mathematically expressed as \(0.5 + 0.1\). Put simply, thirty cents equates fifty percent - both value expressions signify exactly Certainly! direct_answer.text:
To express one third of twenty percent mathematically, first clarify it might sound confusing initially. But let’s simplify this into manageable components – easier ways people relate to better digestion of any notion, right? Just like distributing pieces fairly amidst buddies - remember each piece represents five minutes outta sixty, yes? You got ten folks receiving same shares equalling exactly fifteen collectively till finish line hit zero count again... voila!... Now translate verbally backward following easy language roadmap laid out below…
